SENT.plain: Idiopathic intracranial hypertension is characterized by high cerebrospinal fluid pressure with no underlying structural or systemic cause
Idiopathic intracranial hypertension without papilledema, although well-described in adults, is rarely reported in the pediatric population
The usual presentation is similar to that of chronic daily headache, with some features of migraine
However, treatment modalities are different, and specific therapy can lead to significant improvement in symptoms
We describe six children with chronic daily headache, who were diagnosed with idiopathic intracranial hypertension without papilledema
The response to medical management was variable
One child required a lumboperitoneal shunt for persistent signs, with good surgical outcome
